page.title: 12Lamb-Ale in Kirtlington
page.content: his custom, held on Trinity Monday, originated, we believe, in 1724. All the maidens of the village used to have their thumbs tied behind their backs and a few lambs would be let loose in the field with the maidens. The first maiden to catch a lamb would be the Lady of the Lamb. There was a field containing wheat and barley. The wheat was made into pastry and the barley into ale. The lamb would be part baked, part boiled, roasted and made into a pie. The Festival was revived in 1980 with a procession through the village led by the Lord and Lady of the Lamb. Ladies and children from Kirtlington dress up and join together with Morris Dancers who come from many parts of the country each year. A special Church Service is held,Morris Men dance in the school playground and at local inns. A Feast is held and the Fair visits too.
